article.title: Helsing%C3%B8r
article.paragraph: Helsingr(IPA-dahɛlseŋˈøɐ̯ˀ), also known in English asElsinore, is a city and the municipal seat ofHelsingr Municipalityon the northeast coast of the island ofZealandin eastern Denmark. Helsingr has a population of 46,492 (1 January 2015)"BEF44: Population 1st January, by urban areas"database fromStatistics Denmarkincluding the southern suburbs ofSnekkerstenandEspergrde, and is the largest city and main shopping area in the North Zealand area with over a million visitors a year. It is known internationally for its castleKronborg, whereWilliam Shakespeare's playHamletis set. Helsingr is an important ferry town as theHH Ferry routeconnects northeast Zealand with Sweden.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: The oldest known fortified building of Helsingr isFlynderborg, an early medieval fortress situated on a hill just south of the medieval city.Around 1200, the first church,Saint Olaf's Church, HelsingrSaint Olaf's Church, was built.cite webhttp://www.visithelsingor.dk/ENGELSK/mainmenu.htmlHelsingør Turistbureau - Victoria Designwww.visithelsingor.dk2009-10-21A number of convents once surrounded the church, but now all that remains is the church building, today the cathedral of theDiocese of Helsingr. The oldest parts of the cathedral of Helsingr date back to the 13th century and tell us that the fishermen's village, as Helsingr was then, had grown to a town of importance.

The nameHelsingris derived from the wordhalsmeaning "neck" or "narrow strait", referring to the narrowest point of theresund(re Sound) between what is now Helsingr andHelsingborg, Sweden. The people were mentioned asHelsinger(which may mean "the people of the strait") for the first time inValdemar II of DenmarkKing Valdemar the Victorious'sLiber Census Danifrom 1231 (not to be confused with the Helsings ofHlsinglandin Sweden).early records of Helsingr and Flynderborg ("possibly already mentioned by Saxo"): J. D. Qvist,Annaler for nordisk oldkyndighed, Kongelige Nordiske oldskriftselskab, 1836,p. 306Placenames show that the Helsinger may have had their main fort atHelsingborgand a fortified landing place at Helsingr, to control the ferry route across the strait.

Helsingr as it is known today was founded in the 1420s by the Danish kingEric of Pomerania. He established theSound Duesin 1429, meaning all foreign ships passing through the strait had to pay a toll, which constituted up to two-thirds of Denmark's state income. With this incomeEric of Pomeraniabuilt the castle Krogen. The castle was expanded in the 1580s and renamedKronborg. All ships had to stop in Helsingr to get their cargo taxed and pay a toll to the Danish Crown, but it also generated a significant trade for the town. In 1672 Helsingr had grown into the third biggest town in Denmark.Danske byers historie gennem 1300 rJohan Isaksson Pontanus(Rerum Danicarum Historica, 1631) attributes a long and partially fictitious history to Helsingr.
TheSound Dueswere abolished in 1857 with the1857 Copenhagen ConventionCopenhagen Convention, where all naval nations agreed to pay a one-time fee.
article.heading: Transport
article.paragraph: The car ferry line between Helsingr andHelsingborg,Scania,Swedenis the busiest in the world with more than 70 departures in each direction every day.Helsingborg ferry, compare prices, times and book ticketsThe route is known as theHH Ferry routeand has been sailed by several shipping lines through history. The car ferry terminal is connected to the town's main railway station. From the station, train depart toCopenhagenevery 20 minutes. Trains also depart toHillerdandGilleleje. There are another 6 stations or train stops within the city and connected suburbs. Apart fromHelsingr Station and Ferry TerminalalsoSnekkersten station,Espergrde station,Mordrup stationand the train stops at the line to Gilleleje,Grnnehave,MarienlystandHjstrupGoogle mapshttp://www.moviatrafik.dk/dinrejse/kort/trafikkort/Documents/Hovedstadsomraadet/BusserHelsingor.pdfThe E47 Motorway towards Copenhagen begins just outside the city limits. The town and surrounding areas also has a network of local and regional buses.Kort
article.heading: Industrialisation
article.paragraph: File:Elsinore Shipyard 1938.jpgthumb360pxrightElsinore Shipyard, 1938For a century, a notable site was the:da:Helsingr Skibsvrft og MaskinbyggeriHelsingr Vrftor Elsinore shipyard, which covered the whole area between the town and Kronborg Castle. It was founded in 1882. At its height in 1957, it had 3,600 employees. The last ship left the shipyard in 1983 and it closed the same year following heavy losses.

The:da:WiibroeWiibroebrewery, founded in 1840, was the second brewery in Denmark to ship bottled beer, just three years afterCarlsberg GroupCarlsberg. The last beer was brewed at:da:WiibroeWiibroein Helsingr in 1998.Carlsberg GroupCarlsbergcontinues to brew beer under the Wiibroe rgangslCarlsberg Group - Wiibroe rgangsllabel.
article.heading: Post-industrialisation
article.paragraph: File:Kulturhavn kronborg opened May 2013.jpgthumb360pxrightCulture Harbour KronborgAfter the end of the industrial era, the town of Helsingr had to redefine itself, and came up with an ambitious project:Kulturhavn Kronborg, literally "Culture-harbour of Kronborg". It officially opened on 26 May 2013, intended to appeal to tourists with an interest in culture. The main attraction ofKulturhavn KronborgisKronborg Castle, aUNESCOWorld Heritage Site. Besides the historical attractions of the site,William Shakespeare's playHamletis performed annually in its courtyard since 1937. There is a longstanding tradition of performing the play in English, and notable actors in the title role have includedLaurence Olivier,John Gielgud,Christopher Plummer,Derek Jacobi, and in 2009Jude Law. At the heart ofKulturhavn Kronborglieskulturvrftetor The Culture Yard, a new cultural centre and a public library located in the old:da:Helsingr Skibsvrft og Maskinbyggeridockyard. It opened in 2010. The formerdry docknow houses theDanish Maritime Museum.

In the centre of the harbour basin stands the polished steel sculpture "Han" ("He") by artist duoElmgreen and Dragset, commissioned by the City of Helsingr in 2012. It was inaugurated by then Minister of culture,Uffe Elbk, in June, 2012. It is seen as the counterpart (and even little brother) toEdvard Eriksen's world famousThe Little Mermaid (statue)The Little Mermaidstatue inCopenhagen, and has caused both praise and protests among locals.
The Swedish city ofHelsingborglies a short distance across theresundfrom Helsingr, approximatelyconvert4km0on.European route E55joins the two cities;ferryferriesconnect the two sides.
article.heading: Architecture
article.paragraph: The newDanish Maritime Museumwas designed by Danish prize-winning architectsBjarke Ingels Group(BIG).

Jrn Utzonlived in Helsingr in his youth because his father was an engineer at:da:Helsingr Skibsvrft og MaskinbyggeriHelsingr Vrft. Utzon designed TheKingo Houses(195660) and The Hammershj Care Centre (1962) in the city. The project was completed by Birger Schmidt (1966) after Utzon moved to Sydney to work on theSydney Opera House.
article.heading: Notable natives

list.listitem: Steen Rasmussen(1955present),artificial lifescientist who coined the term "complex systems dogma".
Mikkel Hansen(1987present),team handballhandballplayer who won theIHF World Player of the Year2011.

article.heading: In fiction and popular culture

list.listitem: William Shakespeare's playHamlet(whence the English spelling "Elsinore" derives) takes place mostly atKronborg Castlein Helsingr.
In the 1983 comedyStrange Brew, which is loosely based onHamlet, the protagonists are given jobs at Elsinore Brewery.
InPatrick O'Brian'sAubreyMaturin series, Helsingr firesMortar (weapon)mortar shellsat the heroes in book seven, The Surgeon's Mate, as they sail past on their way to a rendezvous in the Baltic.

In the second chapter ofPhilip Roth's novelOur Gang (novel)Our Gang(1971), Trick E. Dixon in a fictive speech tries to claim Helsingr as US-territory and tries to convince the audience to occupy the area
InBret Easton Ellis's novelLunar Park, the street on which the character Bret Easton Ellis lives, with his own haunting father-son issues, is called Helsingr Lane.
Several stories written by the Danish authorKaren Blixen(or Isak Dinesen) take place in Helsingr, including "The Supper at Elsinore" in her first published volume of stories,Seven Gothic Tales.
A well-known poem by the PortugueseSurrealismsurrealist poetMrio Cesarinyis named "You are welcome to Helsingr".
Children's authorRichard Scarrydepicted Helsingr as "A Castle in Denmark" in the bookBusy, Busy World.
Indie-rock bandThe Essex Greenrecorded a song titled "Elsinore" for their 2006 albumCannibal Sea.

InDavid Brin's novelThe Postman, the first chapter features an apparition that appears to protagonist Gordon Krantz. It is described as an "Elsinorian figure" and greets Gordon with "Alas, poor Gordon!", both allusions toHamlet.
